bestBHT.bht: We are urged to speak well of others and to abstain from quarrels, instead embracing meekness and forbearance. Meekness, born out of a humble spirit, is a social grace that results from our brokenness before God. It involves exhibiting kindness and patience, even in the face of hostility. Let us strive to embody the compassionate nature of the Gospel, demonstrating a gentle and understanding spirit towards all, irrespective of their actions or words.

Henry Alford: to speak evil of no one
manifesting all meekness towards all men
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: To speak evil of no man—especially, not of 'dignities' and magistrates.
gentle—towards those who attack us. Yielding, considerate, not urging one's rights to the uttermost, but forbearing and kindly.
Albert Barnes: We are not to say anything to anyone, or of anyone, which will do him injury.
We should always so speak to him and of him in such a way that he will have no reason to complain that he is an injured man.
We should show that we would rather find him to be a good man than a bad man - even if the result should be that we had been mistaken in our opinions.
Marvin Vincent: No brawlers [αμαχους] . Better as Res., sot to be contentious. See on 1 Timothy 3:3. Past o.
John Calvin: He therefore forbids Christians to glory over others, or to reproach them, whatever may be their own superior excellence.
Not quarrelsome; for there are other ways of fighting than the sword or the fist.
If, therefore, we are disposed to avoid every kind of contentions and fighting, let us learn, first, to moderate many things by gentleness, and next to bear with many things.
Philip Schaff: Meekness is the social grace of character that results from religious brokenness of spirit.
Shows itself in abusing none in words, not being prompt to quarrel, but rather giving way to the insolence of others.
The general idea is, for the rude violence customary in Crete to show the gentle and patient and kindly spirit characteristic of the Gospel.
Archibald T. Robertson: To speak evil (βλασφημειν). See Colossians 3:8; 1 Timothy 6:4.
Not to be contentious (αμαχους εινα). "To be non-fighters" (1 Timothy 3:3), originally "invincible.
John Gill: To speak evil of no man... nor of magistrates, principalities, and powers... which the false teachers were not afraid to speak evil of."
To be no brawlers... not litigious and quarrelsome, wrangling and striving about things to no profit... very unbecoming the followers of Jesus.
But gentle, showing all meekness to all men... carrying it in a meek and humble manner to men of all ranks and degrees... members of the church, or men of the world.
John Wesley: To speak evil — Neither of them nor any man.
Not to be quarrelsome — To assault none.

bhtAttempts.bht: We are called not to speak ill of anyone, especially not of those in authority. Instead, we are to exhibit kindness, meekness, and forbearance towards all. We should refrain from engaging in contentious arguments and instead display a gentle and patient spirit, even in the face of provocation. Meekness is an important quality that arises from a deep sense of humility before God. Our goal should always be to approach others with the assumption that they are good, rather than seeking to find fault in them. In doing so, we bring the gentle and loving nature of the Gospel to a world that may be harsh and unkind.

We are admonished to refrain from speaking evil of others and to avoid quarrels, instead demonstrating meekness and forbearance towards all. This means being gentle and considerate, even when faced with attacks or insults. Meekness is a character trait that arises from a humble and broken spirit. By showing kindness and patience, we bring the compassionate nature of the Gospel to those around us, even when they may display rudeness or hostility. Let us strive to speak well of others and exhibit a spirit of meekness in all our interactions.

In Titus 3:2, we are instructed to refrain from speaking ill of others and to exhibit meekness and forbearance towards all. This means avoiding quarrels and being gentle, even when faced with attacks. Meekness is a manifestation of a humble and broken spirit, a social grace that stems from one's relationship with God. By showing kindness and patience, we reflect the nature of the Gospel to a world that may be characterized by rudeness and hostility.

We are urged to speak well of others and to abstain from quarrels, instead embracing meekness and forbearance. Meekness, born out of a humble spirit, is a social grace that results from our brokenness before God. It involves exhibiting kindness and patience, even in the face of hostility. Let us strive to embody the compassionate nature of the Gospel, demonstrating a gentle and understanding spirit towards all, irrespective of their actions or words.

We are called to refrain from speaking evil of others and to be gentle and meek in our interactions. This means avoiding quarrels and showing forbearance, even when faced with hostility. Meekness is a social grace that comes from a broken and humble spirit before God. By exhibiting kindness and patience, we model the compassionate nature of the Gospel, especially in a world that may be marked by rudeness and contention. Let us strive to speak well of others and extend meekness to all.
